Annelies saw her opening, a path to his heart that bypassed the proud artist. "He knows about her," she said, the lie a necessary, surgical cruelty. "He knows the violin is for her. The perfection he covets is not just in the instrument, Mr. Dekker. It's in the story. The master luthier, his final masterpiece, a gift of love to his musician daughter. That is the treasure he wants to steal. Don't you see? If he takes it, he takes that story from you both, forever. He makes it his. But if you flaw it, you create a new story. A secret between you and the instrument. A maker's mark that no one else can see. It will still be a masterpiece to the world, to your daughter. But to him, it will be spoiled. And it will remain yours."

The fight went out of him. He looked at the violin, the Dekker's Heart, glowing on its velvet bed. It was the culmination of his life, the repository of his skill, his patience, his love. He had intended it as a perfect gift, a piece of his own immortality. Annelies was telling him that its very perfection was a curse, a beacon calling a monster from the depths. He walked slowly to a long, scarred workbench, his back stooped under the weight of the decision. He didn't reach for a hammer or a chisel. His hands, moving with an agonizing slowness, went to a small, custom-made wooden case. He opened it to reveal a set of slender, specialized soundpost setters and files, tools for operating on the very soul of an instrument. He chose a long, thin steel rod with a minutely serrated tip, a tool designed for adjustments so fine they could barely be measured. He turned, the tool in his hand, and his face was a mask of grief, the face of a surgeon about to perform a terrible but necessary amputation on his own child.

Rens started to object, to say something, but Annelies put a firm hand on his arm, her grip surprisingly strong, silencing him. They stood as silent witnesses in the dusty shafts of light. Dekker approached the violin not with violence, but with a surgeon's reverence. He used a small tool to expertly unseat the soundpost, the small wooden dowel inside that connects the front and back of the instrument, the pillar that transmits the vibrations, the heart of its voice. With infinite care, he inserted the long, serrated rod through the f-hole. There was a single, brief, grating sound, a dry, ugly rasp of steel against wood that was a desecration in the sacred quiet of the workshop. It was a sound that lasted less than a second, but it changed everything. He withdrew the rod, reset the soundpost, and stepped back. The violin looked exactly the same. The varnish was untouched, the lines were perfect. But it was irrevocably, fundamentally altered. A tiny, deliberate wound had been inflicted upon its perfect heart.

The old man’s shoulders slumped, and he seemed to shrink, the life force that had animated him draining away into the floorboards. He placed the tool back on his workbench with a hand that trembled violently. "It is done," he whispered, his voice thin and broken. He could not bring himself to look at the violin. It was still beautiful, but he could no longer see the perfection, only the scar on its soul that he himself had carved. Annelies felt a pang of profound empathy for the sacrifice she had demanded of him. She had asked him to break his own heart to save it from being stolen. It was the terrible, paradoxical logic of her new world.

"Now," she said, her voice gentle but clear, breaking the funereal silence, "you must leave. Go to your daughter in Amsterdam. Tell her you needed a break from the city. Do not speak of this. Leave the workshop as it is. Lock the door and walk away." Rens looked at her, his mind struggling to process the plan. "And we just leave it here? As bait?" "It's not bait," Annelies corrected him quietly. "It's a rejected offering. We're not trying to catch him, Rens. We are telling him the item is no longer worthy of his collection." She turned to Dekker. "Give us the key. We will lock up behind you." The old man nodded numbly, his gaze still fixed on some distant point of loss. He fumbled in his pocket and handed a heavy, ornate iron key to Annelies. He took his coat, and without a backward glance at the instrument that had been his life's work, he walked out of the workshop and down the narrow stairs, a ghost leaving his own tomb. The trap, if it could be called that, was set. Annelies and Rens stood alone in the quiet workshop, the flawed masterpiece glowing on its velvet bed, waiting in the encroaching twilight for a response from the encroaching dark.

The twilight deepened, bleeding the colour from the workshop, turning the rows of tools and wood shavings into a landscape of grey and black. The silence that descended after Dekker’s departure was absolute, a vacuum where the sounds of a lifetime of work had once been. The violin, the Dekker’s Heart, lay on its velvet bier, a thing of beauty that now held a secret, ugly wound. It was the only object in the room that seemed to gather the last of the fading light, its amber glow a warm, lonely beacon in the growing dark. Rens moved with a restless, coiled energy, his mind instinctively falling back on the familiar rituals of police work. He pulled a small, high-tech motion-activated camera from his battered briefcase.

“I’ll set this up in the corner,” he whispered, his voice an intrusion in the quiet. “And a parabolic microphone pointed at the street. If someone so much as breathes on the lock, we’ll know.” He was a man adrift, clinging to the wreckage of his procedural training.

“He won’t use the lock, Rens,” Annelies said, her voice quiet but firm, not even turning from the huge window where she stood looking down at the dark, glossy ribbon of the canal below. “And he won’t be seen by your camera. You can’t photograph the tide coming in. You can only feel it when the water is around your ankles.” Her words were pure metaphor, but they held the weight of literal truth. She had felt the presence before, at the de Wit’s house, and it had not been a thing of sight or sound.

Rens stopped, the camera useless in his hand. “Then what are we doing? Just sitting here in the dark? Waiting for a ghost?” The frustration in his voice was palpable. He had committed professional suicide to follow her, and her methods were a form of madness he couldn't rationalize.

“We are listening,” she said, finally turning to face him, her silhouette stark against the pale rectangle of the window. “Not with our ears. We are being still. We are making ourselves a part of the quiet, so we can feel it when something disrupts it. Turn off your phone. We make no light, we make no sound. We wait.” There was no room for argument in her tone. She was no longer his subordinate or even his peer; she was the unwilling high priestess of this dark ritual, and he was merely an acolyte, lost and out of his depth. With a sigh of profound exasperation, Rens put his equipment away, and they settled into a tense, silent vigil on two hard wooden stools, two solitary figures in a room full of ghosts and sawdust.

Hours passed. The city outside muted its roar, the sounds of traffic and life giving way to the deeper, nocturnal hum of a metropolis at rest. Rens fought sleep, his body rigid with a tension that had become second nature to him. His mind raced, trying to build a logical profile, to force the illogical facts into a shape he could comprehend. He saw a man, a brilliant, elderly thief, a master of disguise and infiltration, a theatrical sociopath. Annelies, beside him, seemed to have entered a state of deep, meditative calm. Her breathing was slow and even, her posture relaxed but aware. She wasn't looking for a man. She was listening for the land to speak.

It happened near three in the morning, the dead hour when the world holds its breath. It was not a sound. It was a change in the quality of the silence. A sudden, deep cold permeated the workshop, a damp chill that had nothing to do with the night air outside. It was a cold that seemed to rise from the floorboards, a cold that felt ancient and wet. With it came a smell, faint at first, then stronger, overpowering the familiar scent of wood and varnish. It was the smell of the polder at dusk, of deep, black mud, of decaying reeds and stagnant water. It was the smell of home, the smell Annelies had known since birth, but here, in the heart of the city, it was an olfactory poltergeist, a scent of primal and terrifying wrongness. Annelies’s eyes closed. She did not move, but her entire being became an antenna, tuned to the presence that filled the room.

Rens felt the cold, a shiver tracing its way up his spine. He smelled it too, a foul, boggy odour that made the hairs on his arms stand up. His senses screamed that they were no longer alone. He scanned the darkened room, his eyes wide, his heart hammering against his ribs. He saw nothing. No shadow moved, no floorboard creaked. Yet the feeling of being watched, of a vast and patient intelligence considering them, was overwhelming. The cold deepened, the smell intensified, and then, as suddenly as it had come, it was gone. The air warmed, the scent of sawdust and varnish timidly reasserted itself. The room was empty again. The silence was just silence.

Rens let out a breath he hadn't realised he was holding, his body trembling with adrenaline and confusion. "What in God's name was that?" he whispered, his voice hoarse. "The ventilation? A sewer backup?" He was grasping for a rational explanation, a mundane cause for a moment of pure, primal fear. Annelies opened her eyes. They seemed darker, older, in the gloom. "He has been," she said, her voice a flat, emotionless statement of fact. "The appraisal is complete."

They waited until the first weak, grey light of dawn filtered through the grime on the windows, painting the workshop in shades of ash. Rens, haggard and unconvinced, had dozed fitfully in his chair, while Annelies had remained motionless, a sentinel at her post. "Nothing happened," Rens said, his voice thick with sleep and disappointment as he stood and stretched his stiff limbs. "We sat in the dark all night for nothing. He didn't come." "Let's see," was all Annelies said. She walked toward the center of the room, her movements slow and deliberate. The violin, the Dekker's Heart, lay on its velvet cloth, exactly as they had left it. It was untouched, its flawed beauty undisturbed. Rens let out a frustrated sigh. "I told you. Nothing. It's still here."

But Annelies wasn't looking at the violin. Her gaze was fixed on the workbench where the carved kingfisher had sat. The evidence bag was still there, but it was empty. The beautiful, intricate wooden bird was gone. Rens followed her gaze, his eyes widening. "He took it? But why? Why take the carving and not the violin he came for?" Annelies didn't answer. She pointed to the workbench. Where the kingfisher had been, there was now something else. A small, neat pile of what looked like wet, black soil, flecked with fragments of decaying reeds and what might have been crushed shells. It was a dollop of the primeval swamp, a handful of the deep, dark heart of the polder, deposited with deliberate care on the clean, scarred wood of the luthier’s bench. It was a gesture of supreme and utter contempt.

Rens stared at the pile of mud, his rational mind short-circuiting. The world of forensics and profiling had no category for this. A cat burglar who steals a clue and leaves a pile of dirt in its place was a character from a surrealist play, not a police file. "What is this? A joke? He breaks in, sniffs around, and leaves us… filth? It doesn't make any sense." Annelies looked at the foul offering, the smell of the bog still faintly clinging to it, and she understood perfectly. It was a message, written in a language only she could read. "He came for a perfect thing," she said, her voice low, almost a whisper. "He found the flaw we created. The scar on its soul. He judged it to be worthless." She looked at Rens, her eyes dark with a terrible certainty. "This isn't a joke, Rens. This is his review. He is spitting on our offering. He is insulted. And he is very, very angry." The flawed violin was safe. They had won the battle. But standing there, in the cold morning light of the workshop, Annelies knew with a chilling clarity that by angering the collector, they had just started a much more dangerous war.

Rens stared at the small, dark pile of filth on the workbench as if it were an unexploded bomb. His mind, a finely tuned engine of logic and deduction, sputtered and seized. He had been prepared for fingerprints, for fibres, for a cryptic note left on embossed stationery. He was not prepared for this primal, elemental gesture of contempt. He instinctively reached for an evidence kit from his briefcase, his hands moving through the familiar motions of a cop at a crime scene.

“Don’t bother,” Annelies said, her voice flat. She had not taken her eyes off the pile of mud, but she wasn’t seeing it as evidence. She was reading it as a declaration. “There’s nothing in there your labs can use. It’s a signature, not a clue.”

“It’s evidence of breaking and entering, at the very least,” Rens retorted, his frustration making his voice sharp. He meticulously scraped the wet soil into a sterile container, sealed it, and labelled it with a shaking hand. “I’m going to have every particle of this analyzed. The soil composition, the water salinity, the biological matter. There has to be a trace, a location, something that ties it to a real place, a place I can put on a map.” He was talking to himself as much as to her, trying to force the impossible fact into a box that his worldview could contain. He would find the mud’s origin, and there he would find his Collector.

Annelies watched him, a great, weary pity settling over her. He was still trying to map the ocean with a ruler. The mud had not come from a place he could drive to. It had come from a place that existed in the memory of the water, from the bottom of the polder’s dark, collective soul. It had been brought here by a feeling, an enraged intelligence that did not leave footprints or fingerprints. She left him there, carefully bagging the defiled air of the workshop, and walked down the narrow stairs and out into the waking city. The sun was up now, glinting off the canal, making the old brick facades glow. The world looked painfully, beautifully normal, utterly oblivious to the ancient violation that had just occurred in the room above. She had won. Dekker's Heart was safe. And in doing so, she had picked a fight with a power as old as the land itself. She had not just spurned its advances; she had tricked it, insulted it. And now it knew her name.

Her drive back to the farm was not a retreat. The feeling was different this time. It was not the despair of her suspension or the gnawing guilt of her bargain. It was a cold, clear sense of purpose. The farm was no longer her sanctuary or her prison. It was her territory, the ground upon which the coming battle would be fought. As she turned onto the long track, she saw her father in the distance, standing motionless in the pasture that bordered the main ditch. His posture, even from a hundred yards away, was wrong. It was not the easy stance of a farmer surveying his land, but the rigid, stricken posture of a man bearing witness to a tragedy. A cold dread, sharper and more immediate than any she had felt before, gripped her. She slammed the car to a stop and ran, her boots slipping in the mud, her heart hammering against her ribs.

He didn't turn as she ran up beside him. He was staring down at the pride of their small herd, a magnificent Friesian heifer named Elara, an animal her father had raised from a calf, a cow with a coat like black velvet and a lineage as proud as their own. She was lying on her side at the very edge of the ditch, her legs askew, her head at an unnatural angle. Her big, soft brown eyes were wide open, staring at the grey sky with a placid, shocking emptiness. There was no mark on her, no sign of struggle, no foam at her mouth. She was simply… off. A perfect, healthy animal, the heart of their herd’s future, struck down by an invisible hand. Her father knelt, his big, calloused hand resting on the cow’s still-warm flank. “Her heart just… stopped,” he whispered, his voice thick with disbelief and a farmer’s profound grief. “I saw her grazing not an hour ago. She just laid down, and that was it.”

Annelies looked from the dead cow to the dark, sluggish water of the ditch beside it, and she knew. This was the first volley. The Slikker had been spurned in the city, and it had struck back here, in the heart of her world. It had not taken the cow. It had simply erased her, extinguished her, as a demonstration of its power. It was an attack on her father’s pride, on their livelihood, on the very cycle of life and work that sustained them. It was a punishment, delivered with a cold, terrifying precision. She looked at her father’s devastated face, at the lines of grief etched around his mouth, and the last vestiges of the frightened, bargaining woman she had been dissolved in a blaze of cold, hard fury.

She did not bother with Aart. She didn't need a translator for a message this clear. The rules had been explained. The war had come home. For the next two days, she moved with a methodical, relentless energy. She helped her father with the grim task of disposing of the heifer's body, the loss a heavy, unspoken weight between them. Then, she began to prepare. She walked every inch of the farm's perimeter, not as a farmer checking fences, but as a soldier surveying her battlefield. She noted every ditch, every sluice gate, every place where the water met the land. She spent hours in the old barn, not tending to the animals, but searching through generations of accumulated junk. She found old iron posts, coils of rusted barbed wire, heavy chains from a long-dismantled tractor. In a dusty corner, she found what she was looking for: a box of old, illegal steel leghold traps, relics from her grandfather’s time, saved from a government buyback program out of sheer, stubborn defiance. They were brutal, vicious things, designed to maim and hold.

Her father watched her, his expression a mixture of fear and a grim, ancestral understanding. He saw the cold fire in her eyes, the same look he had seen in old photographs of his own grandfather, a man who had fought the land, the floods, and the Germans with the same intractable stubbornness. He didn't ask what she was doing. He knew, on some deep, cellular level, that she was preparing to fight a war he couldn't see.

On the third night after the heifer’s death, as the mist began its ghostly invasion, Annelies went to work. She did not build a wall. She did not try to keep the water out. She laid a trap. At the edge of the ditch where the cow had fallen, she drove two heavy iron posts deep into the rich, black mud, one on either side of the narrow channel. She stretched a heavy, rust-pitted chain between them, pulling it taut just inches below the surface of the dark, unreadable water. From the chain, she hung two of the steel traps, their serrated jaws open and waiting in the murky depths. It was a crude, brutal, and almost certainly useless gesture. She could not trap the mist. She could not chain the water. But it was not a trap for a body. It was a snare for an idea. A gesture of defiance. It was a line drawn in the mud, a declaration that this land was protected, that its guardian was no longer bargaining. She was fighting back. As she stood, her hands and arms caked in cold mud, the acrid smell of rust on her skin, she looked out into the swirling grey void. The fear was still there, a cold stone in her gut. But for the first time, it was accompanied by something else: a sliver of hope, as sharp and dangerous as the teeth of the traps hidden in the water below. She had made the battlefield her own. Now all she could do was wait for the enemy to make its move.

The waiting was a new kind of work. It settled over the farm like a second, heavier layer of mist, demanding a vigilance that was more exhausting than any physical labour. Annelies moved through her days with the quiet, focused economy of a soldier in a trench. Every chore was a patrol, every glance at the dark line of the ditch was a scan of enemy territory. The rustle of the wind in the reeds, the sudden splash of a fish, the cry of a marsh bird—each sound was intercepted, analyzed, and dismissed. The traps lay hidden beneath the water, a secret of rust and steel she shared only with the land itself. Her father felt the shift in her, the dangerous hum of a wire pulled too tight. He didn't speak of it, but his presence was a constant, silent watch. He started bringing her a thermos of black coffee in the pre-dawn chill as she stood staring at the water, a wordless communion, an acknowledgement of the siege they were under.

Her fragile, self-imposed isolation was shattered by the frantic buzz of her phone four days later. It was Rens. She almost ignored it, but a morbid curiosity, a need to know what phantom he was chasing, made her answer. His voice was a torrent of triumphant, breathless energy. “I got it, Annelies! The NFI report on the mud from the workshop came back. It’s a bullseye. The peat particulates, the specific combination of sphagnum species and fossilized diatoms… they’re unique. They’re a perfect match for core samples taken from the Groot Schijn Veen before it was drained for the A16 motorway expansion in the early '70s. The site's been buried under thirty feet of concrete and asphalt for fifty years!”

She could hear the rustle of papers as he spoke, the sound of a man who had finally found a tangible clue in a world of ghosts. “Don’t you see what this means?” he pressed on, his voice electric with discovery. “Our Collector isn’t some bog-spirit. He’s a man with access. A geologist, an archivist, a university professor… someone with access to sealed historical soil samples. He’s been using this 'ancient mud' as a theatrical calling card. This is the break we needed. I can start pulling personnel files, academic records. I can find him!” He had his straight line. He had found a human explanation so elaborate and convoluted it was almost as fantastic as the truth. He was chasing a brilliant, meticulous librarian with a flair for the dramatic, a man who existed only in the desperate projections of his own rational mind.

“That’s good work, Rens,” she said, the words feeling hollow and distant. She was looking out the kitchen window at the dark, living water in the ditch. Rens’s world was a place of archives and personnel files. Hers was a world where the land itself could remember being a swamp, where it could hold a grudge. The highway had not buried the Groot Schijn Veen; it had merely paved over it. The memory, the essence of the place, still existed in the dark network that connected all the water in the polder. “You follow your lead,” she said, her voice devoid of emotion. “It sounds like you’re on the right track.” She hung up before he could ask her more, severing the connection. The canyon between their realities was now absolute and uncrossable.

Days passed. The tension on the farm became a physical presence, a low hum beneath the daily sounds of life. The other animals were skittish, their instincts sensing a predator their human keepers could not see. The nights grew unnaturally still, the usual chorus of frogs and insects falling silent. The traps in the ditch remained unsprung, the chain untouched. A cold sliver of doubt, sharp and unwelcome, began to work its way into Annelies’s resolve. Had she overreacted? Was the heifer’s death just a tragic, heartbreaking coincidence, a random act of nature that her guilt-ridden mind had twisted into a declaration of war? The thought was both a relief and a terror. To be wrong would mean she was losing her mind. To be right meant she was at war with a god.

The answer came on a morning thick with a mist so dense it felt like a solid thing, a blindfold of wet cotton wrapped around the world. All sound was muffled, swallowed by the oppressive white. As Annelies walked the familiar path towards the ditch, a primal alarm screamed in her gut. The silence was wrong. It wasn't the peaceful quiet of a country morning; it was the profound, waiting silence of a held breath. The air was heavy, charged with a static she could feel on her skin, and it carried the faint, unmistakable smell of the deep bog. He had been here.

She saw it from twenty yards away, a scene of impossible, casual destruction. The two heavy iron posts she had driven deep into the bank were bent outwards at a sharp angle, torn from the mud as if they were mere twigs. The heavy iron chain that had connected them was gone. Not unsnapped, but vanished. The steel traps, the vicious jaws she had set as a warning, were also gone. It wasn’t the work of a man with bolt cutters. This was the work of an immense, careless force, a power that hadn’t bothered to circumvent her trap but had simply dismantled it, erased it, as a man might sweep a spiderweb from his path. Her crude, human defiance had been noted and contemptuously dismissed.

Then she saw the offering. In the dead center of the muddy bank, placed with the chilling precision of a museum curator, sat a small, clear acrylic box. The kind she had used a thousand times in her former life. An evidence box. Inside, nestled on a small square of what looked like black velvet, lay a single object, catching the weak, diffuse light. A pristine, gleaming, 9mm brass shell casing. Her breath caught in her throat. She didn't need to look closer. She knew the faint, unique ejector mark on its base as well as she knew the lines on her own hand. It was from the van Houten case, her first major homicide as a Detective Inspector, seven years ago. A case that had been a tangled mess of contradictions until she had spotted the significance of that one shell casing, a brilliant leap of deductive reasoning that had broken the case wide open. It had been her masterpiece, the moment she had proven to herself and her superiors that she was more than just a competent cop. It was the symbol of her own past perfection. The Collector had not just disarmed her crude physical trap. It had reached back through time, into the heart of the life she had abandoned, and had plucked the artifact of her greatest professional triumph from the locked evidence room of her memory. He knew her. Not just the farmer, but the detective. It was a message of terrifying intimacy. It said, *I see all of you. I can take anything I want. And now, you have my complete and undivided attention.*

The cold plastic of the evidence box felt like a brand against her skin. It was an object from a life she had ceremonially buried, now exhumed and left on her doorstep as a desecrated relic. Annelies stood in the oppressive, muffling silence of the mist, the world shrunk to this small patch of muddy ground and the terrifying intimacy of the message. This was not a random act of spite. This was a scalpel, wielded with a surgeon’s precision, cutting into the soft tissue of her past to expose the exact moment she had considered herself perfect. The Collector had not only read her history; it had understood her pride. A cold dread, far deeper and more personal than the fear for her farm, settled into the marrow of her bones. She had drawn a line in the mud, and the thing from the water had stepped over it to stand inside her own head. With a hand that felt strangely steady, she picked up the box. It was a violation she could not leave exposed to the elements. It was hers now. A trophy from a battle she hadn’t even known she was fighting.

The walk back to the farmhouse was a journey through an alien landscape. The familiar fields, the line of willows, the solid shape of the barn emerging from the grey—it was all a thin veneer, a painted backdrop. The real world was the swirling mist, the dark water, and the patient, predatory intelligence that moved within it. Her father was standing by the gate to the yard, a shovel held loosely in one hand, his posture a silent question. He had heard the change in the silence, too. His eyes fell on the acrylic box in her hand, and his weathered face, a landscape of stoic resilience, seemed to collapse inward. He didn't ask what it was. He saw the shape of it, the clinical geometry of a world that was supposed to be gone, and he understood that it was a message. He looked from the box to his daughter’s face, and in the hard, cold set of her jaw, he saw that the war had ceased to be about the farm. It had become about her. He simply nodded, a gesture of profound and sorrowful solidarity, and opened the gate for her to pass.

In the spartan quiet of her small living room, she placed the box on the worn wooden table. It sat there, a stark, geometric intrusion, a piece of the city precinct marooned in the heart of the polder. The brass casing inside gleamed with a malevolent light, a tiny golden idol of her own past arrogance. She remembered the moment with a clarity that was painful. The van Houten murder scene, a chaotic mess of contradictory evidence. The other detectives were lost, chasing phantom leads. But she had seen it, the single, glinting casing half-hidden under a radiator. She had recognized the obscure ejector mark from a limited run of pistols and had known, in a flash of pure, beautiful logic, that it could only belong to one person. It was a moment of supreme intellectual satisfaction, the perfect alignment of observation, knowledge, and intuition. She had felt, in that moment, untouchable. Invincible. And the thing in the water had felt it too, across the years, and had served it back to her as a threat. The message was clear: there was no part of her life it could not reach, no memory it could not rifle through, no triumph it could not turn into a weapon.

The anger she had felt at the heifer's death, a hot and righteous fury, was gone, burned away by a fear so cold it felt like resolve. Her crude trap had been a gesture of defiance, and it had been met with a demonstration of near-omnipotence. Defiance was not enough. Defence was not enough. She could not build a wall high enough to keep this thing out, because it was already inside her. She needed a new strategy, one born not of anger, but of understanding. She had to learn the nature of her enemy, its history, its weaknesses, if it even possessed such a human concept. There was only one library that held such grim knowledge, only one person who had spoken the forbidden grammar of this war. She left the evidence box on her table, a stark reminder of the stakes, and walked out into the misty day. She was going to see Aart.

He was in his small, cluttered barn, oiling a harness, the scent of leather and lanolin a fragile bulwark against the damp air. He looked up as she entered, his pale eyes registering her presence without surprise. He seemed to have been expecting her. She did not waste time with greetings. She walked over to his workbench and placed the acrylic box upon it, the brass casing a single, jarring note in the symphony of rustic tools. Aart looked at it, his gaze lingering on the shell casing, then on the modern, sterile box that contained it. His hands, which had been moving in a slow, steady rhythm, fell still. A deep, troubled line appeared between his brows. He did not ask her to explain it. He understood the syntax of the Collector’s language. This was a specific and personal escalation.

“You have made it angry,” he said, his voice a low rumble, stating a fact, not an accusation. “It does not like to be tricked. It does not like to be challenged. It is a creature of immense pride.” He wiped his hands on an oily rag and turned to face her fully, his expression more grave than she had ever seen it. “The stories my oma told me… they were for children. Warnings to be humble, to hide your treasures. But there are older stories. The ones the old men would tell only each other, late at night, when the drink was strong and the winter wind sounded like something screaming to be let in. Stories not about what the Slikker takes, but about what it does to those who cross it.” He paused, his gaze drifting out the barn door towards the formless grey of the mist. “The Slikker is the memory of the swamp, Annie. It remembers everything that has ever been lost in it. When it is angry, it does not just take. It trades. It takes a person, and it leaves a piece of the bog in their place. A memory for a memory. The old stories say it can swallow a person’s story. It erases them. Not just their life, but the fact that they ever lived. Their house stands empty, their tools rust, but their neighbours, even their own kin, just… forget them. They feel a sense of loss, like a missing tooth, but they cannot remember what was once there. It makes a hole in the world that is the shape of you.”

The air in the barn grew cold, the dampness seeping into Annelies's bones. The threat was no longer physical loss or psychological trauma. It was existential. It was annihilation on a metaphysical scale. To be erased not just from the future, but from the past. The thought was so vast, so utterly terrifying, that it pushed her past the edge of fear and into a realm of pure, cold clarity. Aart was giving her a warning, but she was hearing an objective. This was not a creature she could bargain with or appease. It was a force that consumed reality itself. You could not defend against that. You could not build a wall against being forgotten. There was only one possible response. She had to attack. She had to find the heart of this memory, this entity, and drive a stake through it. "How do you kill a memory, Aart?" she asked, her voice a dead, level calm that startled even herself.

The old farmer looked at her, and for the first time, he saw not the city cop or the farmer's daughter, but something as old and implacable as the land itself. He saw the grim, unyielding resolve of his own ancestors, the dike-builders and monster-fighters who had carved this country out of the water’s teeth. He gave a slow, weary shake of his head. “You cannot kill the water, Annie. You cannot kill the mud. It has no heart to stab. It has no throat to choke.” He hesitated, then seemed to arrive at a decision, a final, grim piece of knowledge that he had perhaps hoped never to share. “But the stories say it has an anchor. A place of power. The oldest place. The first place that was lost to the water, the one it remembers most fondly. The place where its hunger was born. They called it the Hartveen. The Heart-fen. A piece of land that sank in a great flood a thousand years ago. They say it lies sleeping under the new land, and that everything the Slikker takes, it pulls down into the memory of that place. But no one has known where the Hartveen is for centuries. It is not on any map. It is a story, nothing more.” He looked at her, his eyes full of a terrible, paternal pity. He had given her a target that could not be found, an enemy that could not be killed. He had given her a myth to fight, and he knew that was a war no one could win.

A myth to fight. Aart’s words were a death sentence delivered with the gentle pity of a country doctor. He had given her an enemy with no body and a battlefield that existed only in folklore. Annelies walked away from the old farmer’s barn, the mist clinging to her like a second skin, a tangible manifestation of the impossible story she now inhabited. The Hartveen. The Heart-fen. The words felt ancient on her tongue, a name from a language long dead. How could she possibly find a place that was not on any map, a memory buried under a thousand years of silt and progress? The task was absurd, a fool's errand set by a ghost. She returned to her small farmhouse, the silence within its walls a poor defense against the vast, whispering quiet of the land outside. The acrylic box sat on her table, a stark reminder of her enemy’s reach and precision. The brass casing gleamed, a relic of a life where problems had logical shapes, where answers could be found through deduction and evidence. She had been good at that life. She had been perfect at it, once.

She stared at the shell casing, at the symbol of her own intellectual pride, and a new thought, cold and sharp as chipped flint, sparked in the fog of her despair. The Slikker had used her own history, her own skills, as a weapon against her. It was an intimate, calculated attack. But in doing so, it had made a mistake. It had reminded her of who she used to be. Not the penitent farmer, not the bargaining victim, but Detective Inspector Brandner, a woman who solved impossible puzzles for a living. She had been trying to fight this thing with the tools of the polder—iron posts and traps, the brute force of the land. But this was not a war of shovels and chains. It was a war of intelligence. The Slikker had shown her its own nature—it was a collector, a historian, a connoisseur of detail. She had to become the same. She had to hunt this thing not as a farmer, but as the detective it seemed to remember so vividly.

With a resolve that felt like ice forming in her veins, she picked up her phone. She scrolled past her father’s number, past Aart’s, to the name she had been avoiding for weeks. Her thumb hovered over it, a final moment of hesitation before stepping back across the line she had drawn. Then she pressed the call button. He answered on the first ring, his voice breathless, as if he had been running. “Annelies?”

“Send me everything, Rens,” she said, her voice a low, commanding tone he had not heard in over a year. There was no preamble, no apology. “The complete NFI analysis of the mud from the workshop. The full case files on every incident you’ve linked to your ‘Collector,’ not just the summaries. I want original witness statements, archival photographs, everything. And I need it all in digital format, along with a geo-tagged map of the incident locations. I’m going to help you build your profile.”

There was a stunned silence on the other end of the line, then an audible sigh of relief, a sound of such profound gratitude it was almost painful to hear. “Of course, Annie. Right away. Anything you need. I knew you’d come around. I knew you couldn’t let it go.” He thought she was rejoining his crusade, helping him hunt his phantom serial killer. He had no idea she was about to hijack his entire investigation to hunt a god.

Within the hour, her laptop began to ping with encrypted files. The small farmhouse kitchen, with its smell of coffee and damp earth, transformed into a makeshift incident room. She pushed aside a stack of farming journals and unrolled an old topographical map of the province across the table, securing its corners with salt and pepper shakers. For the next two days, she barely slept. She consumed the data Rens sent, her mind, long fallow, once again firing with the old, familiar patterns of analysis and deduction. She read the files not as a police officer, but as a mythologist, translating the clinical language of the reports into the symbolic grammar of her true enemy. The places it struck, the things it took, the objects it left behind—it was all a language. And for the first time, she had a dictionary.

She read the NFI report on the mud with an intensity that bordered on reverence. Rens had focused on the Groot Schijn Veen, seeing it as a clue to a human source. Annelies saw it differently. The Slikker had not used mud *from* a sample; the mud *was* the sample. It had manifested a piece of a lost place. It was showing off. It was telling her, *I can bring the past into the present*. The report detailed other trace elements, pollen from long-extinct marsh flowers, volcanic ash from an Icelandic eruption in the 9th century, minerals consistent with the erosion of medieval pottery. It was a core sample of a thousand years of lost history. She took Rens’s map of the incidents and layered it over the old topographical survey. She then began adding new layers: historical flood maps from the provincial archive, old Dutch East India Company trading routes that followed the ancient waterways, hand-drawn 17th-century maps from local land registries. The kitchen table became a palimpsest of time, a chaotic collage of data.

A pattern began to emerge, faint at first, then undeniable. The incidents, stretching back over half a century, were not random. They followed the faint, ghostly lines of rivers and tributaries that had been dammed, diverted, or buried for centuries. The Slikker was moving along a network that was no longer on any modern map, a circulatory system of forgotten water that still flowed in the land's deep memory. Then came the breakthrough. On the third night, fueled by black coffee and a cold, burning sense of purpose, she cross-referenced the incident locations with a set of decommissioned geological surveys she’d found on a university server. She was looking for anomalies. She found one. A single, isolated area about thirty kilometers to the east, a place where no incident had ever occurred, but which was the nexus point where three of the major phantom riverbeds converged. The survey noted it as an area of "unexplained gravitational and magnetic variance" with a subterranean peat and silt deposit of "anomalous depth and composition." It was a geological dead zone, a cold spot on every map, a place that made no sense. It was a wound in the land's geology.

It was the Hartveen.

She stared at the screen, her heart a slow, heavy drum. It was under a modern dairy collective, a place of concrete milking parlours and perfectly gridded fields, the epitome of the Netherlands' victory over the chaotic water. But underneath it, sleeping in the cold dark, was the Heart-fen. The place where the Slikker's hunger had been born. Aart had said it was not on any map. He was right. It was not on *a* map. It was on *all* of them, a ghost visible only in the spaces where the data didn’t add up. She zoomed in, the satellite image resolving into the unnervingly geometric shapes of modern agriculture. She placed a single, red digital pin on the coordinates. It pulsed on the screen, a small, bloody X marking a spot that was both an ordinary field and the heart of an ancient, malevolent power. The impossible quest had found its destination. She now knew where she had to go. And she knew, with a certainty that chilled her to the bone, that she would not be going there to talk, or to bargain, or to lay a trap. She was going to war, and her target was the heart of the swamp itself.
